newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Arianespace to launch 70 satellites in next 4 years.
newsitem.headline: Arianespace to launch 70 satellites in next 4 years.

text.p: European satellite launch company Arianespace will launch 70 satellites over the next four years, chairman and chief executive officer Charles Bigot said on Tuesday.

"Arianespace has decided to further increase its launch capabilities by 50 percent -- 70 satellites will be launched within the next four years," he told a news conference at the opening of a regional office in Singapore.
He said the increase was to meet growing demand for telecommunication satellites. He said 50 to 60 satellites were expected to be launched over the next eight years for the Asia-Pacific region alone.
Arianespace had orders to launch 42 satellites over the next 2-1/2 years, 10 of them for Asia-Pacific customers, Bigot said.
"In 1997, we hope to launch 18 to 20 satellites," of which six will be for Asia-Pacific customers, he added.
Arianespace is the leader in the heavy satellite launch market and company officials said it aimed to maintain its 60 percent global market share.
Between 1998 and 2000, Arianespace would use a combination of its existing Ariane 4 rocket and its new Ariane 5 to launch satellites, Bigot said.
Ariane 5, expected to be qualified for commercial use from 1998 after two test flights in 1997, would launch 32 to 34 satellites in 1998-2000.
The rocket, developed at an estimated cost of US$5 billion, was designed to carry two three-tonne satellites at one time and had a reliability rate of 98.5 percent, Bigot said.
Ariane 4's reliability rate was 96 percent, he said.
He said that over the longer term, Arianespace would raise its capacity further and adapt Ariane 5 for changing market conditions.
"First, the satellites to be placed into GTO (geostationary transfer orbit) will become heavier and larger starting from 3000 to 3,500 kg...approaching five or six tonnes," Bigot said.
This was due to strong demand in mobile communications and direct to home television broadcasting needs.
There was also increasing demand for small and medium-sized satellites at lower orbits of 1,000 to 10,000 km.
Bigot said the company was considering using other launchers as Ariane 5 might not be suitable for all new missions.
A first step in this direction was its partnership with Russian Space Agency (RKA) and Samara Space Centre from Russia and Aerospatiale to form Starsem.
Starsem would operate the Soyuz family of low and medium orbit launchers.
Bigot said Starsem had won a contract to launch 12 satellites as part of the Globalstar satellite telecommunications network formed by 56 satellites.
Globalstar is owned by U.S. company Space Systems Loral, part of Loral Space & Communications Ltd.
Starsem would launch the 12 satellites in 1998, Bigot said.
